key_insight: Combining coding-theory–based constrained encodings with learned neural decoders produces a scalable, robust DNA data-storage pipeline that tolerates noisy synthesis and sequencing while improving retrieval reliability and density.
problem_solved: Mitigates high error rates and practical scalability limits of DNA-based archival storage caused by biochemical noise, constrained sequence design, and inefficient decoding.
method: Design of DNA-aware error-correcting codes and constrained encodings that respect synthesis/sequencing constraints (GC content, homopolymers, cross-talk).
Train deep neural decoders to learn complex, real-world error patterns from synthesis/sequencing and to complement classical decoders for improved recovery.
End-to-end co‑design and validation (simulation and wet‑lab/experimental benchmarking) to optimize throughput, density, and robustness.
impact: Demonstrates an AI+coding co-design approach that ML practitioners can apply to noisy-channel problems: using learned decoders alongside principled coding increases reliability and enables practical deployment of novel storage media.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: data -> encoded with constrained ECC -> DNA synthesis -> noisy sequencing -> neural + classical decoding -> recovered data
